titlestmt.subtitle: An inventory of his cartoons at Syracuse University
titlestmt.author: WHL/CAD

list.item: 24 Sep 2009 - added detailed inventory, index; expanded bio (SK)

bioghist.head: Biographical History
bioghist.p:
Dan Dowling (1906-1993) was an American editorial cartoonist who worked for the
Omaha World Herald, the
New York Herald Tribune and the
Kansas City Star.

Born in O'Neill, Nebraska on November 16, 1906, Dan Dowling spent his childhood in Iowa. Dowling was influenced by the cartoons of Jay Norwood “Ding” Darling that appeared in the
Des Moines Register and Leader and Carey Orr. Dowling attended the University of California-Berkeley from 1924 until 1928. Wanting to travel, Dowling joined a dance band and as the drummer got to travel the world. In 1931 he moved to Chicago where he briefly studied at the Academy of Fine Art before working as a police reporter.

In 1933 Dowling joined the Associated Press in New York as a retouch artist. Learning of an opening with the
Omaha World Herald, Dowling moved back to the Midwest in 1937 to become the paper's cartoonist not having had any on the job cartooning experience. Dowling stayed in Omaha until World War II when he joined the infantry and served four years as a captain.

During the war, he submitted cartoons to the
Omaha World Herald and the
New York Herald Tribune. Dowling landed a job with the latter after the war and his editorial cartoons became syndicated in 1949. Dowling stayed at the
New York Herald Tribune until the paper went out of business upon which he became the editorial cartoonist for the
Kansas City Star where he stayed until his retirement.

Dowling won two Freedom Foundation Awards (1956 and 1960), a Christopher Award in 1960, a Sigma Chi Delta award (1960) and served as founding president of the American Association of Editorial Cartoonists from 1956 to 1958.
Dan Dowling retired to Carmel by the Sea, California and died of congestive heart failure on July 27, 1993.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents of the Collection
scopecontent.p:
The
Dan Dowling Cartoons consist of 235 original political cartoons from the years 1960-1966 that appeared in the
New York Herald Tribune and were also syndicated. The cartoons are only marked with years. A few are completely undated. The majority of the cartoons are from 1966.

Dowling's portrayal of figures was typically less realistic and instead very caricaturesque. This can be seen in his treatment of President Lyndon Johnson as a cowboy hat wearing leader who regularly encounters cacti, clearly eliciting Johnson's Texas roots. Like other editorial cartoonists, Dowling visually represented the gamut of domestic and international political issues. For example one of the most heavily represented themes in this particular collection of Dowling cartoons is the economic effect of the Vietnam War. Few cartoons in the collection address issues local to New York.

The cartoons bear the copyright of the Publishers Newspaper Syndicate and the
New York Herald Tribune. The cartoons were created on Glarco illustration board with India ink, brush, graphite and crayon as well as Benday screening.

arrangement.head: Arrangement of the Collection
arrangement.p: The cartoons are arranged in chronological order by year. Within each year the cartoons are arranged alphabetically by caption. A folder of completely undated cartoons is located at the end of the collection.

relatedmaterial.head: Related Material
relatedmaterial.p: &scrc_name; has collections of over one hundred cartoonists. Please refer to &subjindex; for a complete listing.

accessrestrict.head: Access Restrictions
accessrestrict.p: The majority of our archival and manuscript collections are housed offsite and require advanced notice for retrieval. Researchers are encouraged to contact us in advance concerning the collection material they wish to access for their research.

userestrict.head: Use Restrictions
userestrict.p: Written permission must be obtained from SCRC and all relevant rights holders before publishing quotations, excerpts or images from any materials in this collection.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: Preferred citation for this material is as follows:

acqinfo.head: Acquisition Information
acqinfo.p: One cartoon, 1956, gift of Randy Rosen, 2012.

did.unittitle: Doc, will you look at the next pasture?
The seed catalogue and the garden
What a mess to clean up
The bull calf is first to respond
In loving memory of the summer of '62
It says to start turning on the heat
Let's have friendly relations for awhile!
Maybe we had better send for our winter underwear
Red Riding Hood and the wolf
The tail that wags the dog
We've got to have more assurances!
You fellows mind if I slip in ahead?
You sure you're in the right pasture?
Bo Peep has lost a lot of sheep
Boss, it's bound to be a campaign issue!
Everybody get set, here's the big one!
Hello LBJ, it's Hubert. I've finished here, I'm on my way to —
In the name of civil rights
Is this a substitute for the traditional press conference?
On the trail of the lonesome pine
One Memorial Day calls for another
Our theory is, comfortable Communists are less dangerous!
Out where the trade winds blow
A short horse is soon curried
Sorry, we can't get that fellow to vacate the room!
There's a lot more fish in the sea
Warden, you're sure he's locked up tight?
Do we start in where we left off?
The dogs bark and the caravans pass on.
Don't shoot, men, we might hit one of our allies!
I might come in if you all apologize!
I sort of expected my own folks to meet me!
Soon as he has a breather he'll be with you!
Still a lot of empty saddles in the old corral
We've just completed the first 100 days!
All I know is our harbor's being mined!
All we can do is be patient and wait!
Another complaint to the head of the shop
Anything else visible on the landscape?
As we see it, America is a long term paper tiger.
Attention all who follow Soviet affairs
But let's make sure they don't!
Can't we shift into high gear?
Careful, the old boy hasn't gone yet!
Coming in on the slow freight
Could be a step in the right direction
Did you ever see so much soup from one oyster?
Did you have your antenna up around the voters?
For the record I put in the routine threat on Viet Nam
He doesn't want to take on anymore political problems.
He's beginning to drop some hints
Hope you counted the votes right
How we going to work him into the commercial?
I hope the rest of you just sit there and watch
I may start taking you boys seriously!
I understand it won't be 'til after elections
I understand we may run a slower second quarter
I want to file a complaint
I'll read you our program for '66.
Ice has started to form on the river
The idea is not to reward him!
It's been hard on the furniture
It's a long high fly, the Administration is under it!
It's time to make out a new list
I've been working my way toward the head of the line.
Last few holes he's been picking up a gallery!
Let him have a whif, then hit him again!
Let's face it, we may lose some seats!
Little left for those eating at the second table
Maybe I should come out of retirement.
Meet your roomates for the coming year
Nation with the greatest productivity gains in history
Nice idea, maybe we should do it again next year.
None of us are very happy with it.
Not a bad idea to stop off in the far west
Peculiar behavior of a chicken that loses its head
See here, you keep your foot off the accelerator!
Shall we move in for the kill?
Shall we take a look now?
She barely got out of the door
SHHH, we must have absolute quiet.
Some cancellations on the old milk route
Somebody has to make the tackle
Someone is missing from the picture
There was an old lady who lived in a shoe
This happened after I left the farm
Triumph of national interests over ideology
Vice-President Humphrey arrives with the gasoline
Wake up, I just had another brilliant idea!
We don't find that the public is inconvenienced
We don't know much about him, but he's been put in command
We haven't had many good work days!
We heard it many times before but let's hear it again
We might sit a little closer"
We promise the service will be better!
We sure have our lines in a mess
We thought it over and we are of one mind
We want to get our cause back
We're going to have to eat one of 'em
We're going to have to hold things up there
We're just skimming off some of the cream
What are they trying to do?
What are the wild waves saying?
What a chance to be a hero
What ideas you got on how peace can be attained?
Wish we could fight just one war at a time!
Wonder what the post-DeGaulle era will be like?
You can count on a very attentive audience
You can take your little precious home now
You do get the feeling they're living beyond their means
You want to go into consultation?
Somebody's going to have to do something
What's the Viet Nam forecast today?
You all set for another landslide?

note.p: The following is a list of predominant people, places and subjects appearing in the editorial cartoons in this collection. The list is not exhaustive. Some subjects may require you to browse with alternative terms.
B= Box, F= Folder. For example: B1F1= Box 1 Folder 1. The links direct to the cartoon(s) about that topic.
